Award.AwardTitle: Change in the Extratropical Circulation in Response to Global Warming
Award.AbstractNarration:
In simulations of global warming, climate models display robust changes in the global atmospheric circulation. Notable among these is a strengthening and poleward shift of the midlatitude jets. Because these jets are collocated with the midlatitude stormtracks, these shifts imply societally important changes in the distribution of precipitation. While these changes have been documented in many global climate models, a dynamical mechanism has remained elusive, and it remains, therefore, unclear, how much confidence should be placed in them. It has been noted that the simulated changes project strongly on intrinsic modes of unforced variability in the models. The PIs will:
. Identify the changes that occur in the extratropical circulations of global models under greenhouse-gas forcing.
. Relate the structures of such changes to intrinsic modes of variability of model climates, and to use such relationships to predict what changes are likely to occur in the real atmosphere.
. Use experiments with idealized models to isolate those aspects of the response to global warming that lead to the shift in the jets.
. Use experiments with the Community Climate System Model (CCSM) to determine the roles of different aspects of climate change in causing the circulation to change.
. Use simple dynamical models to understand the mechanisms that drive the circulation changes.

Broader impacts of the research are an improved understanding of the credibility of climate-change projections. A graduate student will be trained, and the results of the research will be incorporated in courses taught by the co-investigator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the most robust changes in response to increased greenhouse gases is the strengthening and poleward shift of the atmospheric jet streams. The poleward shift of the jet is a major cause of the expansion of the subtropical dry zones in response to global warming. This drying will have huge potential impacts on agriculture, water resources and ecosystems and therefore a better understanding of the processes and the uncertainty in future projections of this phenomena will have important impacts on society. In the subpolar regions, a poleward shift of the jet stream is a major cause of increased precipitation in response to global warming. 


While this poleward shift of the jet has been documented in many global climate models, the precise dynamical mechanisms responsible for the shift are unclear. Increasing greenhouse gases increase the (vertically-averaged) pole-to-equator temperature gradient ("polar amplification", which acts in the opposite sense, is shallow), and therefore by the thermal wind relationship imply a stronger jet. More idealized models demonstrate that forcing a jet to be stronger also has the unintended effect of shifting the jet poleward so the basic puzzle becomes: why do stronger jets tend to shift poleward (the opposite effect also holds: weaker jets shift equatorward)? A variety of plausible dynamical mechanisms have been proposed, but because of the complex interactions between the jet and the waves that are superimposed on the jet, it is very difficult to separate the contributions and effects of the individual mechanisms. In this research, we developed a model that predicts the correct amplitude and structure of the poleward shift in response to a stronger jet, but that is also simple enough to isolate the mechanisms that generate the waves in the jet from the mechanisms that govern the wave propagation that is essential for maintaining the jet. We use this model to determine which mechanisms are important for the poleward shift and which mechanisms are not. In future we hope to use this model to understand the reasons for climate model jet stream biases, which will hopefully lead to improved climate predictions.


Changes in simulated climate should be considered credible only to the extent that they are robust (i.e. the individual climate models all agree). If certain predictions are not robust, then it is important to identify the reasons for the model uncertainty so that models can be improved. In this research, we have also helped connect model uncertainty in the jet stream response to model uncertainty in the tropical Sea Surface Temperatures (SSTs) response. We suggest that improvements in the simulation of tropical SSTs will lead to more robust simulations of the jet stream as well.
